record.text: last day of steam sale. give me some recs
Hey Will Stancil, it's too late for this sale, but somehow no one has recommended The Talos Principle, a life-changing Thinking Man's Game

Surprised that no one's mentioned Dyson Sphere Program so...

Dyson Sphere Program!

You're a mech shot out to a random system to build a Dyson sphere around the star. Along the way you fly btw planets then eventually other star systems. Very cool Chinese indie game.

Also Timberborn and Factorio.
I play a lot of builders just because they're easy to play for a bit then stop and come back later. Other than that the only thing I've been playing much is Diablo 4.
Captain Of Industry is also a great entry into that genre.
That one's been on my radar and I just haven't pulled the trigger yet
Oh hey another sleeper hit I absolutely can recommend
The hundred line: last defense academy. If you like/tolerate anime bullshit and visual novels- super interesting game with a very twisty plot and a crazy amount of variety.
Slay the Spire
Rimworld is great fun if you've not already played it, and should run fine on your machine even if it's getting on a bit. Complete time-sink though.
I love Rimworld but I get too attached to my little farms, and then when the game inevitably destroys them I want to reload or start over, even though I understand that's not the point of the thing
Have you tried Oxygen Not Included? The physics details in it are awesome in addition to being a great base builder
Hades and Hades 2 are quite fun.

"Factorio". If you've never tried it, it's worth trying, it may eat up your life however. 

"Beyond All Reason" if you like old trad RTS (it's free, open source)

"Deep rock Galactic": Og extraction fps combined with digging 

"Disco Elysium": A tale for the middle-aged to laugh and cry to.

Cryptmaster: Mavis beacon teaches crypt raids

Warhammer rogue Trader: Not quite BG3, but has insane machine-gun Nuns and quite good turned based combat
I assume everyone's already aware of the big ones (BG3, Clair Obscur, overwatch etc)

author.displayName: "We do not see others as they are. We see them as we are."

record.text: Factorio's dev is a TERF. Try Satisfactory, which is just as good if not better.
Rock and stone
the classic fallout games should still be free with twitch prime rn (gog copies but it doesn't really matter, these games are ancient)

Caves of Qud - if you vibe at all with classic roguelikes and maximalist sci-fantasy Dying Earth narratives. Hugo award-winner and the devs are awesome.

You do fight theocratic fascists, cosplaying with trappings of the past they misunderstand, so may not feel as escapist as one might hope....

The Thaumaturge is a very interesting game set just before World War 1 when nationalism and socialism was beginning to fracture the Russian Empire. Terchnically turn-based RPG but more of a mystery game where you summon folklore creatures to investigate and solve mysteries. Rasputin is your homeboy.
Played this a while back, really enjoyed it! Loved the little glimpses into life and culture at the time.

all kinds of stuff! my computer is ancient though

Dunno what‚Äôs on sale but unintensive favs (you‚Äôve played some I‚Äôm sure):

Tactical Breach Wizards
Pentiment
Scarlet Hollow & Slay the Princess
Inscryption
Balatro

Happy to elaborate on these if you want to know what‚Äôs good about em

basically beat inscryption in a single sitting, pentiment kind of put me to sleep in the first hour although I recognize I'd probably love it and should try again, darkest dungeon 1 was a neat concept that became an excruciating grind, is 2 more of the same?

That said if you haven‚Äôt played it I‚Äôd push Tactical Breach Wizards as one of the better gaming experiences I‚Äôve had recently. It‚Äôs a surprisingly well written hybrid puzzle/tactics game that feels very different from a lot of what I‚Äôve played

2 is a very different game - it uses a similar 4 person turn based setup but it‚Äôs a roguelite kind of on rails that resets every run. I never got close to beating 1 and did beat 2 but it‚Äôs def not for everyone! They‚Äôve also added a new mode since I beat it that I haven‚Äôt tried called Kingdoms
Second Tactical Breach Wizards, especially since you said you like puzzle games.

record.text: I definitely own it already lol

Okay then you need to play it. I think you will get a kick out of the dialogue that comes from the communist and fascist playthroughs. Especially when you find the Communist book club on a communist playthrough.

images.alt:
Text from DE that reads:
Mazovian theory and practice. But mostly you'll probably complain about other communists. 

You - isn't that last part kind of kind of productive? 

Rhetoric - not at all. Complaining about other Communists is one of the most important parts of being a communist

Text from DE that reads:
Mazovian theory and practice. But mostly you'll probably complain about other communists.

record.text: I can almost assure you there is no game on sale worth playing before you give Disco Elysium a whirl.

Disco Elysium would be my biggest recommendation for you and it's not close.

Don't look anything up about it. Just play.
I strongly recommend giving it a try. It's well-written, engaging and shockingly inexpensive right now.
Its over one million words of dense political and ideological nitpicking over top of a murder mystery whpdunnit. Youre gonna love it.
And it‚Äôs only $3.99 rn. The story behind the game is almost as intriguing.
I would say darkly and ironically tragic
The story of Disco Elysium is the story of Disco Elysium
Can‚Äôt get over the fact that the actual game was made in an *actual Doomed Commercial Area.*

Disco Elysium is a great game, probably. I couldn't stay awake for it. 
It's like a TV show that fails to grab you in the first hour. 
It probably gets great later, but I couldn't make it.

It gets GREAT later. But it doesn‚Äôt fundamentally change. It‚Äôs just dialogue, plot, and thematics. If you didn‚Äôt make it in the first hour, you could have hung on for another ten and it wouldn‚Äôt have done it for you. Fortunately it‚Äôs one of those that clicks early or not at all.
Disco Elysium is a masterwork, possibly the best writing of any RPG ever.
Beautiful, funny, smart and replayable
Its right up there with Planescape Torment for exceptional writing.

Careful, it might turn him into the most argumentative leftist this site has ever seen.
(j/k, I appreciate him!)
It really is. I have 150 hours because I attempted to get all the dialogue‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt think I ever exhausted all of it. The final cut voice acting is an incredible expression of the writing too.
What am I doing wrong if I find it tedious and slow? How long do I need to stick with it

It‚Äôs not for everyone. It‚Äôs more like a novel than a video game, but the video game mechanics allow it to be several dozen very different novels at once, all with something to say.

I thought it was tedious and slow initially and then came back a year or two later, and now I‚Äôm obsessed.

external.description: ‚ÄúJust one of the purest representations in any art form of what it feels like to have a multifaceted, millions-years-evolved chemistry that‚Ä¶
external.title: Disco Elysium as Modern Literature

record.text:
And I do mean *obsessed*. Here‚Äôs my incredibly long essay on why. I‚Äôd point you to other essays I‚Äôve written about games, but there aren‚Äôt any. I‚Äôve never reacted to a game like I did this one.

Not for everyone, but if it‚Äôs for you and you haven‚Äôt played it yet, man‚Ä¶

external.title: Disco Elysium as Modern Literature
external.description: ‚ÄúJust one of the purest representations in any art form of what it feels like to have a multifaceted, millions-years-evolved chemistry that‚Ä¶

record.text: Ok I‚Äôll read this and see if I‚Äôm up for giving it another shot.
Well, you got the company four of my hardest-earned dollars with that essay. I'm not sure whether it's going to be my cup of tea, but I certainly can see becoming obsessed with this.
Yeah I‚Äôve tried it twice and both times thought ‚ÄúI would like this more as a book than a game‚Äù. Which would be a bummer because I always liked British sea power.

For me what helped was treating it more like a book than a game. Once the Final Cut released I made a point never to skip dialog to move the game along faster (like I do in virtually all RPGs - who‚Äôs got the time?) and instead savor the pace and the language. Helped shift my perspective.
co-sign, just an incredible piece of work that everyone should at least give a shot

Jeez, $4? 
I was pondering Baldurs Gate 3 at $45
BG3 is top 3 RPGs all time, worth it to own, too! Disco Elysium is a totally different beast though; no combat in the traditional sense but incredibly good writing.

So your answer I should get both? 

If I do, they average only $24... the more I buy the more I save!
Yes, you‚Äôll get two of the best games in the last decade

Well heck if I buy BG3, DE, and Witcher III I'm down to $17 per game.

That's a great deal for BG3!
Cosigning Disco for the nth time here, incredible game that has been cursed with some of the most insufferable fans at times but absolutely a must-play nevertheless
Wait, what‚Äôs the third?
I'd say the Witcher 3, which you can get for $3 or $4 right now. Hell of a deal for all the gameplay which comes with it.
I would vote Red Dead Redemption 2

some contenders:

Witcher 3 (my personal choice)

the Mass Effect trilogy (2 is the best of them, imo)

KOTOR
It took me a long time to get around to it, but Witcher 3 is unbelievably good. So is Cyberpunk (story not as good, character building much more fun).
in its current form Cyberpunk 2077 is also a real contender, especially Phantom Liberty, which is one of the best expansions of anything I‚Äôve ever played
Witcher 3 might have to be my comfort replay this winter! ME and KOTOR would be good too, but I‚Äôve replayed them more
You know what you‚Äôre right, Witcher 3 over my other two choices. And I forgot KOTOR as an option, that‚Äôs also up there.
Witcher 3 is on sale for $4 right now, $10 with both (incredible) DLCs.
Suggesting Suzerain for both of ya'll too if you haven't played yet.
KCD2, I hope!ü§û
Still haven‚Äôt played it but need to
I think you‚Äôll love it - every month for several months. So much excellent content.

I realize I‚Äôm backtracking a bit but it seems odd to put Disci Elysium and BG3 in the same RPG category. The latter has more in common with adventure games and point and clicks despite having a robust RPG system.

But if I had to pick, Mass Effect (series as a whole package) or Fallout 2.
Mass Effect is just such a ball. I did the series a few years ago when I had an itch for space opera.
The former, not the latter. Whoops.
If you like game mechanics around narrative storytelling and morality systems, you gotta try The Alters.

Thank you for posting about this, I am very excited and wouldn't have realized DE was on sale without you and Will Stancil!

Frostpunk & Frostpunk 2: City and society building during an ice age. You have some very fun steampunk aesthetics and a ton of moral choices where no one is going to be happy.

Pages and pages of recs and only a handful of duplicates. Ain‚Äôt nobody got time for this!
Chants of Sennaar, puzzle/adventure game
Until I played this, I had no idea that linguistic puzzle games were my jam. It was so satisfying and so adorable.
Rimworld
If you haven‚Äôt played Baba is You, it‚Äôs one of my favorite puzzle games of all time.
Baba Is You is excellent, but my top three puzzle games would have to be Stephen's Sausage Roll, The Witness, and Yugo Puzzle (sequel to the also-great Jelly No Puzzle).
You know, I liked the Witness in principle, but it turns out that even with a lot of beautiful scenery my appetite for maze puzzles peters out around the three hour mark.
That's fair. I felt like the different areas gave it enough variety, but it is a long game.

What I particularly like about SSR and Jelly No Puzzle is that they are very transparent about what is possible (while still being very hard), so the solutions always feel earned. What's both cool and sometimes frustrating about Baba Is You is that the solutions are often quite off-the-wall.
I love it, someone mentioned it earlier and I rebooted it for the first time in years

Tunic is quite well-beloved by the same sorts of folks who love those games. It presents as a Soulslike riff on Legend of Zelda but it goes way deeper and unraveling it is so much fun.

Outer Wilds is like forbidden fruit to me because I want to play it soooo bad but can't do first person perspective bc migraines. So desperate I'm trying to steer the teenager into game dev so she can make a version I can play.

Antichamber is my favorite game of all time, and it's currently only $5. Amazing atmosphere, good mix of musing tone and intellectual exploration, mind-bending shit that'll be fun if you liked blue prince
you played any of the zachtronics puzzle games?
opus magnum, what else is good?
infinifactory for sure, it's not too far above opus magnum in difficulty. both are on the easier side of his games, good starting titles
Lorelei and the Laser Eyes, Chants of Sennaar

I like puzzles and I think point and click adventure games appeal to a similar sensibility. For those I recommend most anything developed by wadjeteye games. They also publish games and they tend to do a good job on those, too
You might like Sable then
Not as puzzle heavy as outer worlds but similar vibes
If you liked Obra Dinn and Golden Idol, you *must* play "The Roottrees Are Dead."
If you liked Obra Dinn/idol (same here) I highly recommend The Roottrees Are Dead about piecing together the complicated family tree of a wealthy family

the myst and riven remasters
obduction
"The Roottrees are Dead" and "Hypnospace Outlaw" are favorites in the puzzle genre. Both also have a retro-90s/early aughts internet interface that's a lot of fun, but implemented very differently.
Hypnospace has a b-plot about right-wing radicalization online through fringe conspiracy sites that I think you might enjoy.

author.displayName: Walter is not in the Epstein files

record.text: This is a solid top list. If you haven't yet, you could check out The Roottrees Are Dead, it's cut from similar cloth.
If you haven‚Äôt played Talos Principle and Talos Principle 2 it‚Äôs a MUST
balatro
Buy Gorogoa and Monument Valley 1, 2, and 3. Manifold Garden is good too.
The Roottrees are Dead scratches all of those itches imo.
subnautica might be a top 5 game for me too, and I'm basically afraid to play the second one because I know it doesn't hold up

author.displayName: "We do not see others as they are. We see them as we are."

value.text: Subnautica is literally my favorite game ever. Subnautica: Below Zero is... ok? Compared to the first one, it's a pretty major disappointment.

record.text: Below Zero is fine.  It‚Äôs not as good as the original but it‚Äôs fine.

author.displayName: "We do not see others as they are. We see them as we are."

record.text: 'fine' is fair, IMHO. It's just not up to the sterling standard of the first.

I‚Äôm glad they tried new things from a narrative perspective.  It‚Äôs too bad they didn‚Äôt keep stuff like the Sea Moth.  The Sea Truck had its cool features but wasn‚Äôt as good as Sea Moth or Cyclops.

author.displayName: "We do not see others as they are. We see them as we are."

record.text: I found the Seatruck very unsatisfying. But I was never big into the Cyclops, either. I just Seamoth'd everywhere and built a bunch of bases to support a Prawn wherever I needed to go deeper.
My last play through I put in a bunch of mods which had additional Seamoth depth modules.  So much fun to zip around the lava zones even if it was strictly speaking not intended by the devs üò¨

author.displayName: "We do not see others as they are. We see them as we are."

record.text: I did some dumb stuff in the lava zone to avoid having to get a Cyclops down there. Took the Seamoth as deep as it could go, then built a base about 100m below that, then dropped minibases down the lava tube for oxygen until I got to the [SPOILERS] area.
okay I'm hearing this a lot

value.text: If you liked Obra Dinn and Golden Idol, you *must* play "The Roottrees Are Dead."

record.text: Yeah, if you haven't already played it, that was a pretty good one.  Fairly short, but scratches that same general itch.

Other games in the same category as Roottrees/Obra Dinn (though not quite as good): "Rivals" (about a fictional alt-country band's history) and "A Case of Fraud".

Similar-but-differerent AND just as good: "Strange Horticulture" and "Strange Antiquities".

I will co-sign that, it's not as good as Obra Dinn, but will scratch that itch.
For Seance at Blake Manor, I would recommend a notepad, the game's very good at storing info for you, but there are one or two places where that info can get lost in the midst of everything else it's storing.

I really wish there was a better name for the genre of environmental puzzle games where the puzzles are mostly about careful observation of seemingly mundane or irrelevant details. they tend to have interesting narratives, probably because the people who make them are so good at layering details
I think you‚Äôre talking more about games like Myst with this post (and some of the old Nancy Drew games there‚Äôs a very niche community for), but highly recommend Animal Well for puzzles
Also, Arx Fatalis plus mods

record.text: I think of these as "puzzle island" games. (Being set on a literal island is not a requirement but helps)

yeah, these games are all the spiritual successors of myst (which was in theory like this, but in reality had very traditional puzzles). not coincidentally, and I just realized this right now, myst was the very first video game I ever binged through, at the age of 9

value.text: I think you‚Äôre talking more about games like Myst with this post (and some of the old Nancy Drew games there‚Äôs a very niche community for), but highly recommend Animal Well for puzzles

record.text:
I'd say most of them are spiritual successors of Riven more than Myst, which was better at being like this

Speaking of, the Riven remake from 2024 is fantastic.

I've seen them called knowledge-based puzzle games, or "Metroidbrainias" (which is definitely too clever and insular)
my computer in 1997 couldn't really handle Riven, too much video, it was choppy and unplayable. so I never played it. didn't realize there was a remake
No Fromsoft interest?
yes that's exactly what they should call them. you nailed it

value.text: I think of these as "puzzle island" games. (Being set on a literal island is not a requirement but helps)

record.text: Taiji was nice and satisfying. The puzzles were at a fairly nice level of complexity.

Oh, speaking of Puzzle Island games, there's also _Paradise Killer_, which is...different than the ones we were talking about but probably shares some DNA. Worth looking at if the sale price is right.
Also, Quern: Undying Thoughts (which starts VERY strong but then kinda falls off at the end.)
I mean in that case - the Witness
How about ‚ÄúHeaven‚Äôs Vault‚Äù for a linguistic + archaeological puzzle vibe?

saw Roottrees are Dead mentioned so many times in this list that I bought it, and it's eaten up my last two evenings. loved the process of researching online to find clues (especially as someone who was using the internet in 1998) and loved the story that evolved

Baba Is Me
Ah, another fun suggestion - if you haven't played Chants of Senaar it's a great <10 hr indie about communicating across different languages. Context-clues-as-puzzles

You should follow @thinkygames.com, they cover games just like that. My wife and I both love games like this too. Thinky games has been a great resource. 

Blake Manor, Tunic, The Swapper and all the Myst games are my suggestions.

Have you ever played The Witness? Great puzzle game. 

Hexcells (and Hexcells Ultimate) is also a great evolution of Minesweeper.
Played hexcells long ago, just bought The Witness on someone‚Äôs recommendation
So we won‚Äôt be seeing you around here for a while then? Hope you like Edward Grieg!
Also if you haven‚Äôt played Pentiment it‚Äôs a great point and click

Such an underrated gem, this game ‚Äî stuck with me way after I finished it

Plus, so many cool medieval/early-Renaissance details to appreciate!
Workers and Resources Soviet Republic
If you ever played Sierra or LucasArts's old adventure games, the two Kathy Rains and the Excavation of Hob's Barrow are great throwbacks.
Big fan of Scarlet Hollow: An episodic supernatural adventure by the makers of Slay the Princess (also highly recommended). Episode 5 coming out soon. Not sure it's on sale tho.
Tactical Breach Wizards

How far back?

Older: 

* Both Ori games 
* Subnautica 
* Inside
* Half Life Alyx (if you have VR abilities)

* Journey
* Immortality

Newer:

The Long Dark
Any of the Owlcat RPGs (Kingmaker, Wrath of the Righteous, Rogue Trader)
Important caveat: as long as real time with pause doesn‚Äôt drive you up the wall
Hey now both Pathfinders have turn based as an option and Rogue Trader is turn based only.

They didn‚Äôt when I tried them. I will have to look again, that but turn based sounds great. 

Rogue Trader was great for like half of it but the combat way overstayed its welcome.
which is your fave? Been eyeing them

Kingmaker is a little old (in game terms) and doesn't have some of the QOL improvements Wrath does, but it's an amazing story and I sank a lot of 2020 Covid downtime into it. Build guides and, TBH, some game guides are helpful because you can get softlocked very easily, esp. by kingdom management

WOTR interface and bugginess is much improved from Kingmaker, but the companions are less interesting, and it can be easy to stare at a list of feats for two hours and brainlock. You do get to rock a lot of Godlike powers and spells, you definitely feel like a Demi-God in combat

I'm only through Act I of Rogue Trader, strong so far, very reflective of WH40K - I think I'm about where the story kicks really kicks in. Very stable, character progression is much easier and forgiving.
Wrath of the righteous! Don't be afraid to play on an easier difficulty if you don't feel like learning the specifics of pathfinder rules
Wrath of the righteousness is amazing but you will have to master Pathfinder 1e rule set, which is like d&d 3e on steroids. It is very possible to build your character incorrectly and suck.

ymmv (this is not everyone's playstyle obviously) but WOTR is pretty fun to play on very low difficulty so you don't have to worry about stuff like that. still helps to have a grasp of the basics of course.
(I have played lots of tabletop PF1E but playing at normal difficulty would still have been pretty hard)
I used the trick called lowering the difficulty in fights I was struggling with (most of them at the end of it, but hey).
I spent a lot of time with 3e/Pathfinder in my 20s so after I got back up to speed/refreshed myself I was cool with playing at the tabletop difficulty. But it's extremely unwelcoming.
For example: the most important spell in the game is Grease. Everything else is secondary to slippery-ass floors

"I am going to build a dual wieder and..."

NO! Oh God no!

You simply must know every single possible malus and the buff that counters it and then stack every bonus imaginable to hit the monster weakness you know or have managed to impose by bypassing their magic resistance using another series of system masteries.
i tried to like the owlcat crps until i realized that a) build is super important and b) the fucking tooltips literally will not tell you how anything works
(because they want you to buy the pathfinder rulebooks)
To be fair everything is freely available at Archives of Nethys. P1e and 2e are both under open gaming licenses.
Learning the feats to make all your 5m buffs last 24h is a godsend in just making the game playable, but you neeeed to be using a guide to get those feats
The difference between 3e grease and 5e grease, man.

This reminds me of the old gold box D&D games. One or more of them had a bug where nobody could make a saving throw. This combined with the rule that it only took 1 point of damage to kill something made Hold Person + 3 darts a murderous combination.
Kingmaker is best if you like optimising multiple interlocking systems simultaneously - I loved what everyone else hated about it (optimise your crew for murderhoboing about AND ruling).
I loved it except the last chapter versus the lantern King where you have to rebuild your strength. That was a miserable sloh.

Rogue Trader personally but I'm a big 40k fan. 
Kingmaker vs Wrath probably depends on which one you like the vibe of more (establishing your own kingdom in cursed wild lands vs a crusade against demons)
Rogue Trader is really fun, agreed, but fair warning to Will that it‚Äôs a huge timesuck, it took me 91 hours to complete, which meant like 3 months given working life.
Amateur

Abiotic Factor.

Its basically an homage to a certain mid 2000s game named after some nuclear materials terminology.

The plot kicks off with you transferring in from another facility, and right as you arrive, the elevator you're on breaks, and everything goes to heck. Now you want out.

record.text: Road Redemption
DROD: Journey to Rooted Hold is an absolutely amazing puzzle game. My all time favorite. The sequels are good too!
If you like deck builders then I can recommend fights in tight spaces or slay the spire
Meditative puzzle games- both of the FAR: games by okomotive

If you're into sandbox games, Transport Fever 2 and Workers & Resources are both top notch, the first for its refinement in the series and the latter for merging the urban planner and management game in an unfamiliar setting

Outer Wilds is amazing and I assume you‚Äôve played the DLC? Haven‚Äôt found anything else quite like it but Jonathan Blow‚Äôs two games, Braid and The Witness, are both pretty good as well. My favorite game of last year (and perhaps last several years) is Clair Obscur: Expedition 33.
If your computer meets the reqs, Metaphor Re:Fantazio is like Poli Sci the JRPG. But vastly more fun than that sounds
It's a fantasy game about the runup to an election - your character is running against socialists, fascists, supremacists, gerontocracy, and Roger the Libertarian
this looks goofy af and I love it
Came here to recommend this. I love that game, not only because it's charming and the gameplay is great, but also because it's basically a full-throated defense of liberalism and utopianism.
Yes! It really is a battle cry against illiberalism. It was absolutely brutal for my household that we beat it just after e-day 2024

The last spell, if you like tactical/roguelite. Or Breachway. Anything published by Hooded Horse. Monster Train / Monster Train 2. Midnight Suns. Cobalt Core. Demote for a more modern Plants vs. Zombies.

Last Spell is incredible. Just unbelievably good composition of game elements. Every match feels like, oh my gods, I am about to be devoured, but somehow you end up surviving. Ridiculously good. Fantastic atmospherics.
I haven't seen Viewfinder listed yet in the thread, and I think it fits your puzzle interests.
